The Reserve Bank confirmed on Friday that our economic future looks bleak indeed.

FULL TEXT

To the extent we didn't know it before, the Reserve Bank (RBA) has confirmed that our economic future looks bleak indeed until well into the 2020s. The bank put together three scenarios for the economy in Friday's August Statement of Monetary Policy, which is now our most up-to-date official view of the economy -- the government's July economic update having been, through no fault of Josh Frydenberg, comprehensively trashed by events in Victoria. Even the RBA's "baseline" scenario, seen as most likely, paints a miserable few years for Australians. The Great Morrison Stagnation that was the world pre-COVID will seem like nirvana in 2021 and 2022. And we still don't really know how the recovery will play out -- the RBA admits (as it has done for a while now) that it is very difficult, if not impossible, to be confident about key economic estimates more than three months into the immediate future. Nevertheless. "It is expected that there will be ample spare capacity in the labour market over the next few years, with broader measures of labour market underutilisation remaining elevated," the RBA says. "Consumption is not expected to reach its pre-COVID-19 level until early 2022 ... household income is expected to decline over coming quarters as government support is tapered." The RBA is also pessimistic about business investment other than mining. It expects it won't start recovering until after household consumption has picked up again. "The timing and pace of the recovery in non-mining investment remains highly uncertain, but is expected to lag the recovery in consumption. This reflects the assumption that firms will first use up spare capacity as demand picks up, as well as the typical long lags in the planning and approval of construction projects. By the end of the forecast horizon, non-mining business investment is forecast to still be below its pre-pandemic level." That will be a key impediment to jobs growth, and will create a vicious circle in which households aren't spending because of a lack of jobs growth, and businesses aren't investing, and putting on more staff, because households aren't spending. That was the kind of rut we were stuck in before the pandemic: the 2018-19 budget forecast of non-mining investment growth of over 5% ended up at just 1.6%; a similar forecast in last year's pre-election budget was drastically revised down to 2% in last year's Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook, long before anyone had heard of COVID-19. Getting businesses investing is thus a key challenge of the October budget. Business, of course, is insisting that reducing company tax, making it easier to cut wages, increasing the GST and deregulation will get them investing, and the government is sympathetic to that view. Even if we accept those arguments from business (in the face of evidence), there are other impediments to investment and innovation that the government can control. It's now well-established that growing market concentration in the US over the last two decades has led to overly high profits (at least according to the organ of socialism, The Economist) and declines in business investment. Labor's Andrew Leigh has long studied and written about the problem from an Australian perspective, where if anything we have a significantly more concentrated economy. The current recession will exacerbate this problem. As smaller, more marginal businesses succumb to the recession, larger businesses survive and enjoy greater market share. Competition regulators and governments are more likely to approve mergers of failing businesses with successful competitors. That happens in every recession. But the pandemic has also entrenched the power of big yech. Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Googlehave all unveiled results recently that show them essentially impervious to the historic contraction underway -- or, in the case of Amazon, actually benefiting from it. These companies are now significantly larger than all but the biggest economies around the world. That was before the Trump administration decided it wanted one of the big tech firms to compulsorily acquire TikTok, one of the few successful competitors to big tech's dominance outside China. The only way to address the problem of concentration undermining investment is an aggressive application of competition law that reduces concentration. Business hates that idea with a passion -- witness the hostile reaction to the Turnbull government's idea for divestment powers in energy regulation, something even Labor thought was outrageous. But failing that, a low-competition, low-investment future beckons, with permanent implications for economic growth.

The Reserve Bank confirmed on Friday that our economic future looks bleak indeed.

FULL TEXT

To the extent we didn't know it before, the Reserve Bank (RBA) has confirmed that our economic future looks bleak indeed until well into the 2020s. The bank put together three scenarios for the economy in Friday's August Statement of Monetary Policy, which is now our most up-to-date official view of the economy -- the government's July economic update having been, through no fault of Josh Frydenberg, comprehensively trashed by events in Victoria. Even the RBA's "baseline" scenario, seen as most likely, paints a miserable few years for Australians. The Great Morrison Stagnation that was the world pre-COVID will seem like nirvana in 2021 and 2022. And we still don't really know how the recovery will play out -- the RBA admits (as it has done for a while now) that it is very difficult, if not impossible, to be confident about key economic estimates more than three months into the immediate future. Nevertheless. "It is expected that there will be ample spare capacity in the labour market over the next few years, with broader measures of labour market underutilisation remaining elevated," the RBA says. "Consumption is not expected to reach its pre-COVID-19 level until early 2022 ... household income is expected to decline over coming quarters as government support is tapered." The RBA is also pessimistic about business investment other than mining. It expects it won't start recovering until after household consumption has picked up again. "The timing and pace of the recovery in non-mining investment remains highly uncertain, but is expected to lag the recovery in consumption. This reflects the assumption that firms will first use up spare capacity as demand picks up, as well as the typical long lags in the planning and approval of construction projects. By the end of the forecast horizon, non-mining business investment is forecast to still be below its pre-pandemic level." That will be a key impediment to jobs growth, and will create a vicious circle in which households aren't spending because of a lack of jobs growth, and businesses aren't investing, and putting on more staff, because households aren't spending. That was the kind of rut we were stuck in before the pandemic: the 2018-19 budget forecast of non-mining investment growth of over 5% ended up at just 1.6%; a similar forecast in last year's pre-election budget was drastically revised down to 2% in last year's Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook, long before anyone had heard of COVID-19. Getting businesses investing is thus a key challenge of the October budget. Business, of course, is insisting that reducing company tax, making it easier to cut wages, increasing the GST and deregulation will get them investing, and the government is sympathetic to that view. Even if we accept those arguments from business (in the face of evidence), there are other impediments to investment and innovation that the government can control. It's now well-established that growing market concentration in the US over the last two decades has led to overly high profits (at least according to the organ of socialism, The Economist) and declines in business investment. Labor's Andrew Leigh has long studied and written about the problem from an Australian perspective, where if anything we have a significantly more concentrated economy. The current recession will exacerbate this problem. As smaller, more marginal businesses succumb to the recession, larger businesses survive and enjoy greater market share. Competition regulators and governments are more likely to approve mergers of failing businesses with successful competitors. That happens in every recession. But the pandemic has also entrenched the power of big yech. Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Googlehave all unveiled results recently that show them essentially impervious to the historic contraction underway -- or, in the case of Amazon, actually benefiting from it. These companies are now significantly larger than all but the biggest economies around the world. That was before the Trump administration decided it wanted one of the big tech firms to compulsorily acquire TikTok, one of the few successful competitors to big tech's dominance outside China. The only way to address the problem of concentration undermining investment is an aggressive application of competition law that reduces concentration. Business hates that idea with a passion -- witness the hostile reaction to the Turnbull government's idea for divestment powers in energy regulation, something even Labor thought was outrageous. But failing that, a low-competition, low-investment future beckons, with permanent implications for economic growth.

The Reserve Bank confirmed on Friday that our economic future looks bleak indeed.

FULL TEXT

To the extent we didn't know it before, the Reserve Bank (RBA) has confirmed that our economic future looks bleak indeed until well into the 2020s. The bank put together three scenarios for the economy in Friday's August Statement of Monetary Policy, which is now our most up-to-date official view of the economy -- the government's July economic update having been, through no fault of Josh Frydenberg, comprehensively trashed by events in Victoria. Even the RBA's "baseline" scenario, seen as most likely, paints a miserable few years for Australians. The Great Morrison Stagnation that was the world pre-COVID will seem like nirvana in 2021 and 2022. And we still don't really know how the recovery will play out -- the RBA admits (as it has done for a while now) that it is very difficult, if not impossible, to be confident about key economic estimates more than three months into the immediate future. Nevertheless. "It is expected that there will be ample spare capacity in the labour market over the next few years, with broader measures of labour market underutilisation remaining elevated," the RBA says. "Consumption is not expected to reach its pre-COVID-19 level until early 2022 ... household income is expected to decline over coming quarters as government support is tapered." The RBA is also pessimistic about business investment other than mining. It expects it won't start recovering until after household consumption has picked up again. "The timing and pace of the recovery in non-mining investment remains highly uncertain, but is expected to lag the recovery in consumption. This reflects the assumption that firms will first use up spare capacity as demand picks up, as well as the typical long lags in the planning and approval of construction projects. By the end of the forecast horizon, non-mining business investment is forecast to still be below its pre-pandemic level." That will be a key impediment to jobs growth, and will create a vicious circle in which households aren't spending because of a lack of jobs growth, and businesses aren't investing, and putting on more staff, because households aren't spending. That was the kind of rut we were stuck in before the pandemic: the 2018-19 budget forecast of non-mining investment growth of over 5% ended up at just 1.6%; a similar forecast in last year's pre-election budget was drastically revised down to 2% in last year's Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook, long before anyone had heard of COVID-19. Getting businesses investing is thus a key challenge of the October budget. Business, of course, is insisting that reducing company tax, making it easier to cut wages, increasing the GST and deregulation will get them investing, and the government is sympathetic to that view. Even if we accept those arguments from business (in the face of evidence), there are other impediments to investment and innovation that the government can control. It's now well-established that growing market concentration in the US over the last two decades has led to overly high profits (at least according to the organ of socialism, The Economist) and declines in business investment. Labor's Andrew Leigh has long studied and written about the problem from an Australian perspective, where if anything we have a significantly more concentrated economy. The current recession will exacerbate this problem. As smaller, more marginal businesses succumb to the recession, larger businesses survive and enjoy greater market share. Competition regulators and governments are more likely to approve mergers of failing businesses with successful competitors. That happens in every recession. But the pandemic has also entrenched the power of big yech. Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Googlehave all unveiled results recently that show them essentially impervious to the historic contraction underway -- or, in the case of Amazon, actually benefiting from it. These companies are now significantly larger than all but the biggest economies around the world. That was before the Trump administration decided it wanted one of the big tech firms to compulsorily acquire TikTok, one of the few successful competitors to big tech's dominance outside China. The only way to address the problem of concentration undermining investment is an aggressive application of competition law that reduces concentration. Business hates that idea with a passion -- witness the hostile reaction to the Turnbull government's idea for divestment powers in energy regulation, something even Labor thought was outrageous. But failing that, a low-competition, low-investment future beckons, with permanent implications for economic growth.

urn:contentItem:60KB-1H51-JD6R-T0NH-00000-00Reserve Bank flags a low investment future as we concentrate our way to stagnation2020-08-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:40ZLexisNexisReserve Bank flags a low investment future as we concentrate our way to stagnationCrikeyABSTRACT

The Reserve Bank confirmed on Friday that our economic future looks bleak indeed.

FULL TEXT

To the extent we didn't know it before, the Reserve Bank (RBA) has confirmed that our economic future looks bleak indeed until well into the 2020s. The bank put together three scenarios for the economy in Friday's August Statement of Monetary Policy, which is now our most up-to-date official view of the economy -- the government's July economic update having been, through no fault of Josh Frydenberg, comprehensively trashed by events in Victoria. Even the RBA's "baseline" scenario, seen as most likely, paints a miserable few years for Australians. The Great Morrison Stagnation that was the world pre-COVID will seem like nirvana in 2021 and 2022. And we still don't really know how the recovery will play out -- the RBA admits (as it has done for a while now) that it is very difficult, if not impossible, to be confident about key economic estimates more than three months into the immediate future. Nevertheless. "It is expected that there will be ample spare capacity in the labour market over the next few years, with broader measures of labour market underutilisation remaining elevated," the RBA says. "Consumption is not expected to reach its pre-COVID-19 level until early 2022 ... household income is expected to decline over coming quarters as government support is tapered." The RBA is also pessimistic about business investment other than mining. It expects it won't start recovering until after household consumption has picked up again. "The timing and pace of the recovery in non-mining investment remains highly uncertain, but is expected to lag the recovery in consumption. This reflects the assumption that firms will first use up spare capacity as demand picks up, as well as the typical long lags in the planning and approval of construction projects. By the end of the forecast horizon, non-mining business investment is forecast to still be below its pre-pandemic level." That will be a key impediment to jobs growth, and will create a vicious circle in which households aren't spending because of a lack of jobs growth, and businesses aren't investing, and putting on more staff, because households aren't spending. That was the kind of rut we were stuck in before the pandemic: the 2018-19 budget forecast of non-mining investment growth of over 5% ended up at just 1.6%; a similar forecast in last year's pre-election budget was drastically revised down to 2% in last year's Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook, long before anyone had heard of COVID-19. Getting businesses investing is thus a key challenge of the October budget. Business, of course, is insisting that reducing company tax, making it easier to cut wages, increasing the GST and deregulation will get them investing, and the government is sympathetic to that view. Even if we accept those arguments from business (in the face of evidence), there are other impediments to investment and innovation that the government can control. It's now well-established that growing market concentration in the US over the last two decades has led to overly high profits (at least according to the organ of socialism, The Economist) and declines in business investment. Labor's Andrew Leigh has long studied and written about the problem from an Australian perspective, where if anything we have a significantly more concentrated economy. The current recession will exacerbate this problem. As smaller, more marginal businesses succumb to the recession, larger businesses survive and enjoy greater market share. Competition regulators and governments are more likely to approve mergers of failing businesses with successful competitors. That happens in every recession. But the pandemic has also entrenched the power of big yech. Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Googlehave all unveiled results recently that show them essentially impervious to the historic contraction underway -- or, in the case of Amazon, actually benefiting from it. These companies are now significantly larger than all but the biggest economies around the world. That was before the Trump administration decided it wanted one of the big tech firms to compulsorily acquire TikTok, one of the few successful competitors to big tech's dominance outside China. The only way to address the problem of concentration undermining investment is an aggressive application of competition law that reduces concentration. Business hates that idea with a passion -- witness the hostile reaction to the Turnbull government's idea for divestment powers in energy regulation, something even Labor thought was outrageous. But failing that, a low-competition, low-investment future beckons, with permanent implications for economic growth.

urn:contentItem:5TV0-3X41-F19Y-C2JN-00000-00Reshaping financial rules not about bank vs. big tech, German watchdog says2018-11-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:40ZLexisNexisExtraReshaping financial rules not about bank vs. big tech, German watchdog saysVanya Damyanova

As technological innovations flood financial services, regulators must spot trends that could threaten market integrity instead of finding new ways to define what a bank is, according to BaFin President Felix Hufeld.

Technological innovation is rapidly changing the financial services market and regulators need to redesign the scope of existing rules. However, supervising Google or Amazon as a bank is not the way to do that, according to Felix Hufeld, president of German financial regulator BaFin.

Regulators must spot trends that could threaten the integrity of financial markets, instead of designing a new definition of banking services, Hufeld said at the European Banking Regulation conference in Frankfurt. New rules should be imposed only when technology-driven ventures need to bear certain responsibilities to safeguard that integrity, he said.

"We want to supervise technology in a neutral fashion. We don't want to supervise companies just for the sake of technology," he said during a Nov. 20 panel discussion.

Although the likes of Amazon and Google already offer banking-related services, they have no incentive to become a bank as it would be "highly dilutive" to their share price, he said. Furthermore, it would be easy for nonfinancial firms to establish a front-end structure that could have a bank license that is based on a data-driven business model, but not on the actual value creation, which will happen somewhere else, he said.

Banks feel threatened by competition from big technology companies that offer a whole range of other services to global customers and could easily include banking offerings. Technology groups such as Apple, Samsung, Google and others are already offering solutions, especially in the payments space. Banks are concerned that in the long run they will lose primary contact with clients to global technology groups.

Those corporations already have a dominant market position and are not keen on sharing the space, Christian Ossig, CEO of the Association of German Banks, BdB, said during the discussion. He referred to a 2014 speech by PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel that "competition is for losers."

"These big techs, which from a current market perspective are not regulated, might become systemically relevant not only because they have entered the financial services market but because they are also service providers to banks today," Ossig said, noting that apart from its 50% market share in e-commerce, Amazon has a significant share of the cloud-services market as well. Therefore, regulators should tighten the rules and think of a new definition of systemic importance, Ossig said.

No need to 'reinvent the wheel'

Responding to Ossig's comments, Hufeld said "the basic idea of redesigning the scope of financial regulation is a must" and there is a need for an "engaged dialogue" to gradually arrive at "conclusions [on] how to modernize and improve regulation."

However, that must not necessarily mean a fundamental change in definitions. Hufeld cited carmakers as an example, saying that although Volkswagen and Daimler are not under BaFin supervision per se, they have certain ad hoc publication responsibilities that they need to follow. If they breach these responsibilities, the financial regulator gets involved, he said.

Similar tools that are fit for a broader ecosystem, including nonfinancial companies, could be developed for banking services as well, "safeguarding the integrity of financial markets regardless whether you are called Google, or Amazon or something else," Hufeld said.

"It's not at all impossible to create regulatory structures to enlarge the space and scope of financial supervision without having to reinvent the wheel," he said.

Tech-neutral approach is key

European banks, in particular, are under pressure to digitize their services given their high costs and low profitability, and they are also "being challenged on all fronts by innovators and third-party institutions," said panelist Adam Farkas, executive director at the European Banking Authority.

Innovators are always striving to become the monopoly in their markets, he said. However, financial regulators cannot impose new rules for all technological innovations that come into the market, he said. They need to monitor closely and understand the new technology businesses and their interconnectedness with the financial services sector to apply targeted rules which would ensure a level playing field, Farkas said.

"When virtual currencies became the headlines of the day in 2014, we identified 74 areas of regulation but we decided we should not go that far to regulate the left, right and center of every aspect of them," he said.

In the end, the EBA recommended bringing virtual currency exchanges and wallet providers under the market regulator's remit as they were providing services that in the traditional market space are heavily regulated due to anti-money laundering concerns, Farkas said. "And that is an example of a level playing field in regulation," he said.

"Where I would criticize the industry in that sense is that sometimes we feel [banks] are trying to promote the use of financial regulation to block competition and I think that should not be used for defensive purposes," Farkas said.

urn:contentItem:5XYF-CYC1-DXVP-V02R-00000-00Resignation;Google legal chief leaving amid sexual misconduct troubles2020-01-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:40ZLexisNexisCALIFORNIAPg. 7ResignationGoogle legal chief leaving amid sexual misconduct troublesBarbara Ortutay; The Associated Press

David Drummond, the legal chief of Google parent company Alphabet, is leaving at the end of the month, following accusations of inappropriate relationships with employees.

Alphabet did not give a reason for Drummond’s departure in a short regulatory filing Friday.

The company said in November that its board was investigating sexual misconduct cases against executives. Claims against Drummond were included in the investigations.

Thousands of Google employees walked out of work in 2018 to protest the company’s handling of sexual misconduct claims. The board investigation followed lawsuits brought by shareholders after reports of sexual harassment at Google received national attention.

Last August, a former Google employee, Jennifer Blakely, published a report of her relationship with Drummond. Drummond has acknowledged a relationship with Blakely. But in a statement at the time, he said he “never started” a relationship with anyone else at Alphabet.

The company said Drummond is not getting an exit package as part of his departure. His compensation package for 2018 was worth $47 million, making him one of the company’s highest-paid employees, according to regulatory filings.

In a memo sent to employees, Drummond said that with founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin “now leaving their executive roles at Alphabet, the company is entering an exciting new phase, and I believe that it’s also the right time for me to make way for the next generation of leaders.”

He did not mention the misconduct allegations.

Drummond said Page and Brin asked for his help more than 20 years ago when what became Google and Alphabet was just an unincorporated startup. Drummond joined Google full time in 2002 and was named chief legal officer in 2006.

Drummond’s departure comes as Alphabet, like other big tech companies, faces regulatory pressures around the world. Last March, Europe’s antitrust regulators ordered it to pay $1.7 billion for freezing out rivals in the online advertising business.

urn:contentItem:5TVM-9MK1-F11P-X2B0-00000-00Resilient Microsoft Stock Remains a Long-Term Winner2018-11-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:40ZLexisNexisResilient Microsoft Stock Remains a Long-Term Winner

Amid the recent technology sector rout, one mega-cap tech stock has weathered the storm with shocking and impressive resilience. While its peers are all more than 15% of their recent highs, and many have dropped 30% or more, Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) currently trades just 8% off its all-time highs.

That is shocking. MSFT is typically viewed as similar to the FAANG names i.e. its seen as a mega-cap tech stock with lots of growth opportunities. But while all of the FAANG names are essentially in bear-market territory. MSFT stock isnt even in correction territory.

The resilience of MSFT is impressive and a testament to the strength of the companys fundamentals. There are a few headwinds that are weighing on mega-cap tech stocks. But none of those headwinds affect MSFT. Instead, MSFT stock is still being powered by continuous tailwinds related to artificial intelligence (AI) and data which arent slowing all that much.

MSFT should be strong for the foreseeable future. The growth of MSFT is powered by AI and data, and it has limited exposure to increased regulation, higher tariffs, and rising interest rates. As a result, as long as AI and data continue to grow rapidly, Microsoft stock will continue to be the most resilient mega-cap tech stock in the market by a long shot.

Since AI and data will continue to quickly proliferate in the near, medium, and long terms, MSFT stock will both continue to weather the near-term volatility of the tech sector and head significantly higher in the long-run.

Prevailing Headwinds Wont Affect MSFT

In simple terms, the headwinds which are dragging down the FAANNG names simply do not apply to Microsoft stock.

Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) is nearly 40% off its all-time highs because of regulation concerns, the slowing growth of its digital ad business, and its increased spending on security which is compressing its margins. Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) is more than 20% off its all-time highs because of its exposure to tariffs, valuation concerns, and slowing retail growth. Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) is 25% off its all-time highs because of slowing iPhone demand and plenty of exposure to China and tariffs. Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) is 35% below its all-time highs because of valuation concerns and the pressure that rising interest rates will place on its debt-loaded balance sheet.

Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) is down 50% from its peak due to its exposure to tariffs and the sudden end to the cryptocurrency mining craze. Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOG) has dropped 20% below its all-time highs due to regulation concerns, the slowing growth of its digital ad business, and the fact that its margins are dropping because of a continued shift to mobile ads.

So there are a few headwinds which are weighing on mega-cap tech stocks. The growth of companies that are exposed to digital ads is under pressure. Rising interest rates are pressuring the stocks of companies with sky-high valuations and those with a bunch of debt. Tariffs are reducing demand for impacted products and pushing costs higher. The cryptocurrency hype has ended, and thats creating a drag on anything related to crypto. And increased regulation of big tech is as big a threat today as its ever been.

MSFT isnt plagued by any of these headwinds.

The company has some, but not much, exposure to digital ads through its Bing search engine, so lower prices for digital ads arent catastrophic for Microsoft stock. Meanwhile, MSFT trades at a fairly average forward multiple of 24, and the company has far more cash than debt on its balance sheet. Since the companys valuation and debt levels are reasonable, it shouldnt be hurt much by rising interest rates.

Also, tariffs werent mentioned once on Microsofts recent earnings conference call, and thats because the company hardly has any exposure to potential tariffs at the moment. MSFT also doesnt have any crypto exposure, nor has it been under the regulation microscope like Facebook and Alphabet.

Overall, the headwinds which are dragging down big tech stocks simply dont apply to MSFT stock. That is why Microsoft stock has been impressively resilient during this tech stock rout.

Microsofts Growth Remains Robust

Whereas the growth of most other mega-cap tech companies is slowing, Microsofts growth is actually accelerating.

This was the big takeaway from Microsofts strong first-quarter earnings report. Its rapidly growing cloud business remains on fire, and despite the current macroeconomic headwinds, Microsofts overall growth trajectory continues to improve. At the beginning of fiscal 2016, Microsofts revenue was declining. By the beginning of fiscal 2017, its revenues were growing 2%-3%. At the start of fiscal 2018, its revenue growth was in the 10%-plus range. Now, at the start of fiscal 2019, its revenue growth is nearing 20%.

The acceleration of Microsofts revenue growth has been very impressive, and it is entirely due to Microsofts cloud revolution. This revolution is still in its early innings. It is estimated that only 20% of enterprise workloads have migrated to the cloud thus far. Inevitably, that number will reach 100% in the long-run, implying that Microsofts biggest growth driver has plenty of room to accelerate.

More importantly, within the cloud sector, Microsoft has become the best-in-class. In the cloud world, Amazon, Microsoft, and Alphabet are known as the Big Three. But the Big Three is increasingly becoming the Big Two as Microsoft Azure is emerging as a solid runner-up to Amazon Web Services, and Google Cloud is becoming a still-formidable but much smaller third wheel. Moreover, Azure is growing far faster than AWS (Azure is growing at a 76% clip versus 46% for AWS), so the big winner in the continuously-growing cloud space right now is Microsoft.

Because of this, Microsoft stock should benefit from solid and improving growth drivers in both the near-term and the long-term. As the cloud revolution goes global and AI and data become more important than ever, Microsofts growth trajectory will only improve, and MSFT stock will head higher.

The Bottom Line on MSFT

The headwinds affecting other mega-cap tech stocks dont apply to MSFT. Meanwhile, the tailwinds keeping other tech stocks at above-average valuations do apply to MSFT stock.

As a result, Microsoft should remain resilient in the near term and become a winner in the long-term. 2018 Global Data Point.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, September 6th. Your top stories right now just after 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Critic in the midst -- President Trump with choice words for the supposed administration official who wrote a scathing op-ed for the "New York Times".

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: When you tell me about some anonymous source within the administration, probably who is failing and probably here for all the wrong reasons. And the "New York Times" is failing. If I weren't here, I believe the "New York Times" probably wouldn't even exist.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The fallout from the White House this morning coming up.

Meanwhile, markets are looking higher today, futures indicating a fractional gain at the start of trading. But look what's just happened actually in the last 20 minutes. S&P 500 and the Nasdaq have turned negative; Dow Industrials are up 12, S&P down 1, Nasdaq down 6 -- more of a mixed story on top of a mixed story yesterday on Wall Street.

The major indices were mixed with the Dow finishing up 22 points at the close but the Nasdaq and the S&P were negative. The Nasdaq down better than 1 percent yesterday.

In Europe this morning, the indices are also mixed. FT 100 down 10 points, the CAC 40 in Paris is up 5 but the DAX index in Germany is down 6.

Asian markets finished lower overnight -- take a look. Worst performer Hong Kong, down about 1 percent.

Crypto crisis -- bitcoin and other crypto currencies taking a big hit. We're taking a look at what's behind this slide this morning.

And a big night for football -- the NFL season opener kicks off tonight. We will see if the new Colin Kaepernick Nike ad airing in the game will bench viewers.

Forget those napkins -- a new grease-proof X-Box controller set to make it easier for gamers to enjoy snacks while playing the game.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down: our own Dagen McDowell; PWC partner Mitch Roschelle; and The Hill columnist, Fox News contributor Liz Pete. Great to see everybody this morning.

LIZ PETE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: So much to talk about.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: Another busy news day.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes. And we've got the jobs number out tomorrow.

ROSCHELLE: We've got ADP today.

BARTIROMO: We have the ADP number today on jobs. We're talking about all of the gossip coming out of the White House and the name calling. And really most Americans want to know about their economic future and the backdrop there. We'll get another window into that tomorrow.

PETE: Yes. And actually the Fed, Atlanta Fed, just came out with a 4.7 percent estimate for the third quarter, which is pretty astounding, right. That may be why we have this op-ed in the "New York Times", by the way, more good news on the economic front, that has to be countered by Democrats.

BARTIROMO: That's exactly right. As he continues to have successes, particularly economic successes, detractors are going insane. They're losing their minds.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: I keep a list of all the good news on the economy.

BARTIROMO: I like that.

MCDOWELL: This is literally just in the past week-and-a-half, maybe 10 days -- 18-year high consumer confidence, the job market. We actually have a labor shortage in some ways in this country. Manufacturing activity -- factory sector strongest growth in 14 years. I could go on. But we have guests.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we do. We have a lot coming up.

But you're right. It's the story of the Trump administration, the economic success that is unnerving his detractors.

Joining the conversation this morning, we're going to speak with the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Iowa Senator Chuck Grassley is here. Former senior advisor for President George W. Bush, Karl Rove weighs in this morning. Along with Hall of Fame basketball coach, author of "Pitino: My Story", Rick Pitino joining us this morning with that story. And the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY" Stuart Varney weighs in as well.

Don't miss a moment of it. We've got a big two hours coming up.

We kick this hour right off with this -- President Trump just tweeting on North Korea this morning. He says this. "Kim Jong-un of North Korea proclaims, quote, 'unwavering faith in President Trump'. Thank you to Chairman Kim. We will get it done together."

Yes. The North Koreans now say they want to denuclearize and the President there, Kim Jong-un has confidence in President Trump, he says.

Our top story this hour: resistance from within. An anonymous "New York Times" op-ed claims to be a top Trump official working to thwart the President at every turn. Trump blasting the inside critic in Washington yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: If the failing "New York Times" has an anonymous editorial. Can you believe it? Anonymous -- meaning gutless, a gutless editorial -- we're doing a great job. The poll numbers are through the roof. Our poll numbers are great.

And guess what? Nobody is going to come close to beating me in 2020 because of what we've done.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me now to talk more about that is New Jersey Congressman Leonard Lance. He's also on the House Energy and Commerce Committee and he questioned Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey yesterday. We'll get to that in a moment -- sir.

Congressman -- thanks very much for joining us this morning. Good to have you.

REP. LEONARD LANCE (R-NJ), HOUSE ENERGY AND COMMERCE COMMITTEE: Thank you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Your thoughts on this op-ed this morning?

LANCE: I prefer signed op-eds. And I think that the "New York Times" should have requested who actually wrote it. And I think it leads to the opinion of quite a few that we need to have specificity in this area. And I would hope that the "New York Times" might agree with that.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean at this point it's not anything different than we've heard from the President's detractors. It's more of the same. And this particular op-ed is somebody saying what we've heard from his detractors for the last year-and-a-half but unwilling to put his name to it.

LANCE: That is correct. And let me say, I have great faith in General Kelly and, for example, in General Mattis. And certainly I think that the editorial should have been signed -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: And what about great faith in President Trump -- sir? Do you have faith in him?

LANCE: I agree with the President in some of his policies. I disagree with others of his policies. But regarding the system of government we have, Maria -- we have checks and balances here in Congress. Indeed that's what's occurring at the moment in the Senate with the nomination of Judge Kavanaugh -- advice and consent.

And I believe in our system of government. And As you pointed out at the top of the hour, the economy is very strong at the moment.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about the technology CEOs and executives grilled on Capitol Hill yesterday. Twitter stock yesterday took a tumble after the House questioned CEO Jack Dorsey over bias against conservatives. You specifically asked him about the algorithm's fairness. Let's take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JACK DORSEY, CEO, TWITTER: We need to understand as we use this artificial intelligence for more and more of the things that we do that, number one, that they're unbiased outcomes; and number two, that they can explain why they made the decision in the first place.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Do you feel like you -- do you feel like you got the answers you were looking for -- Congressman?

LANCE: I think that remains to be seen. And Mr. Dorsey said Twitter would be doing a better job in the future. Was the bias intentional or unintentional? I'm not sure.

But regardless of that, there should not be bias -- Maria. And it's now the responsibility of Twitter and other companies -- Google, for example -- to make sure that there is no bias.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I know, but I mean, he's blaming the algorithms and saying we want the algorithms to be fair.

I mean we're not stupid. Algorithms don't come out of magic. Somebody programs the algorithms. Did you get at who is programming the algorithms and what they're looking at in terms of metrics to put the algorithm together?

LANCE: He was asked that. And you're obviously precisely right that this is based upon human input. And we want to make sure that human input is in no way biased against conservatives, for example.

And I do not believe Twitter has done a good job in the past. And it has to do a much better job in the future; and that was the opinion of the committee. And that is why Mr. Dorsey came before the committee.

BARTIROMO: So before we move on -- I want to ask you about the Kavanaugh hearing -- but before we move on from this, what are the potential drawbacks for the tech companies? I mean what can you actually do in terms of Congress writing a new law? What do you think plays out from this?

LANCE: Of course, we're the committee of jurisdiction for legislation. I am not there yet. I would prefer to have a situation where there doesn't need to be further legislation but that remains to be seen, Maria, based upon what these companies do in the future.

And incidentally I was disappointed that Google chose not to show up on the Senate side of the Capitol yesterday.

BARTIROMO: Now, will you subpoena Google? Where does that go in terms of Google just blowing it off?

LANCE: I think it's a decision in the Senate as to whether the Senate wishes to subpoena. And I hope regarding future invitations, Google will come in voluntarily -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Congressman -- let me switch gears, the Senate heading into day three of questioning Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh. He took a stance on respecting and enacting the law, congress decides. Watch this.

If parents want to go see their child play and you're making millions of dollars off that young man's athleticism, they should be able to have their flights and hotel paid for to go see that young man play, especially during March Madness in the tournament. Every game those parents should be able to be put up in a hotel and if flights should be paid for.

MCDOWELL: Well, you said it was unfair to colleges if they took you on as a coach because of -- it would expose them to the allegations. But has anybody really approached you? Have you -- did you get phone calls from other colleges or even professional teams?

PITINO: I had two job offers last year. We talked. We sat down. One president came in and was nice enough to visit with me. And then there was another school, I was interested in --

MCDOWELL: Do you want to tell us which schools?

PITINO: I'd rather not. But the other school I was -- I was interested in. They called the NCAA and said, can you give us clearance on Rick Pitino, he did nothing wrong. Their response to us, we can't investigate anything until the Southern District of New York is done with their -- with whatever they're doing.

BARTIROMO: So what, do you have a time line in terms of when they're done? Are they done at this point?

PITINO: I don't know. I know there's some things are going to trial yet in September. Nobody from Louisville, not myself. I'm not involved in any way. And I have no fears about any of that because I know what I've done with college basketball and I know what I believe in my beliefs in doing it the right way and we do it like most coaches.

By the way, I believe that less than 10 percent of college basketball is corrupt. I think 90 percent of college basketball, people do it the right way, their hearts are with the student athletes. They want to help those young men prosper in life.

But like any industry, whether it's Wall Street, whether it's the medical professional, less than 10 percent does it the wrong way.

BARTIROMO: Right.

PITINO: And that's what needs to be cleaned up.

BARTIROMO: Sure, we're going to be watching that Rick. Thanks so much for joining us, telling us your story.

PITINO: Thanks for having me.

MCDOWELL: Good luck.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you coach.

PITINO: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Rick Pitino there.

Still ahead, a major shift for Burberry, the changes headed to the luxury goods maker. Next hour right here, MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Thursday to you. It is Thursday September 6th. Your top stories right now just after 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

END
