urn:contentItem:5T6J-J5D1-DXH2-637V-00000-00Resistance from Within; Tech on Capitol Hill; Supreme Court Showdown; Crypto Crisis; NFL Season Opener Tonight; Dara Khosrowshahi: Uber is Ready for a 2019 IPO; Harvard Remains Number One in Wall Street Journal College Rankings; Rick Pitino on NCAA College Recruiting Scandal2018-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:40ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMitch Roschelle, Leonard Lance, Rick PitinoNEWSFinancial090602cb.231Resistance from Within; Tech on Capitol Hill; Supreme Court Showdown; Crypto Crisis; NFL Season Opener Tonight; Dara Khosrowshahi: Uber is Ready for a 2019 IPO; Harvard Remains Number One in Wall Street Journal College Rankings; Rick Pitino on NCAA College Recruiting ScandalMaria Bartiromo, Liz Pete, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Jared , Susan Li, Liz Peek

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, September 6th. Your top stories right now just after 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Critic in the midst -- President Trump with choice words for the supposed administration official who wrote a scathing op-ed for the "New York Times".

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: When you tell me about some anonymous source within the administration, probably who is failing and probably here for all the wrong reasons. And the "New York Times" is failing. If I weren't here, I believe the "New York Times" probably wouldn't even exist.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The fallout from the White House this morning coming up.

Meanwhile, markets are looking higher today, futures indicating a fractional gain at the start of trading. But look what's just happened actually in the last 20 minutes. S&P 500 and the Nasdaq have turned negative; Dow Industrials are up 12, S&P down 1, Nasdaq down 6 -- more of a mixed story on top of a mixed story yesterday on Wall Street.

The major indices were mixed with the Dow finishing up 22 points at the close but the Nasdaq and the S&P were negative. The Nasdaq down better than 1 percent yesterday.

In Europe this morning, the indices are also mixed. FT 100 down 10 points, the CAC 40 in Paris is up 5 but the DAX index in Germany is down 6.

Asian markets finished lower overnight -- take a look. Worst performer Hong Kong, down about 1 percent.

Crypto crisis -- bitcoin and other crypto currencies taking a big hit. We're taking a look at what's behind this slide this morning.

And a big night for football -- the NFL season opener kicks off tonight. We will see if the new Colin Kaepernick Nike ad airing in the game will bench viewers.

Forget those napkins -- a new grease-proof X-Box controller set to make it easier for gamers to enjoy snacks while playing the game.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down: our own Dagen McDowell; PWC partner Mitch Roschelle; and The Hill columnist, Fox News contributor Liz Pete. Great to see everybody this morning.

LIZ PETE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: So much to talk about.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: Another busy news day.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes. And we've got the jobs number out tomorrow.

ROSCHELLE: We've got ADP today.

BARTIROMO: We have the ADP number today on jobs. We're talking about all of the gossip coming out of the White House and the name calling. And really most Americans want to know about their economic future and the backdrop there. We'll get another window into that tomorrow.

PETE: Yes. And actually the Fed, Atlanta Fed, just came out with a 4.7 percent estimate for the third quarter, which is pretty astounding, right. That may be why we have this op-ed in the "New York Times", by the way, more good news on the economic front, that has to be countered by Democrats.

BARTIROMO: That's exactly right. As he continues to have successes, particularly economic successes, detractors are going insane. They're losing their minds.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: I keep a list of all the good news on the economy.

BARTIROMO: I like that.

MCDOWELL: This is literally just in the past week-and-a-half, maybe 10 days -- 18-year high consumer confidence, the job market. We actually have a labor shortage in some ways in this country. Manufacturing activity -- factory sector strongest growth in 14 years. I could go on. But we have guests.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we do. We have a lot coming up.

But you're right. It's the story of the Trump administration, the economic success that is unnerving his detractors.

Joining the conversation this morning, we're going to speak with the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Iowa Senator Chuck Grassley is here. Former senior advisor for President George W. Bush, Karl Rove weighs in this morning. Along with Hall of Fame basketball coach, author of "Pitino: My Story", Rick Pitino joining us this morning with that story. And the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY" Stuart Varney weighs in as well.

Don't miss a moment of it. We've got a big two hours coming up.

We kick this hour right off with this -- President Trump just tweeting on North Korea this morning. He says this. "Kim Jong-un of North Korea proclaims, quote, 'unwavering faith in President Trump'. Thank you to Chairman Kim. We will get it done together."

Yes. The North Koreans now say they want to denuclearize and the President there, Kim Jong-un has confidence in President Trump, he says.

Our top story this hour: resistance from within. An anonymous "New York Times" op-ed claims to be a top Trump official working to thwart the President at every turn. Trump blasting the inside critic in Washington yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: If the failing "New York Times" has an anonymous editorial. Can you believe it? Anonymous -- meaning gutless, a gutless editorial -- we're doing a great job. The poll numbers are through the roof. Our poll numbers are great.

And guess what? Nobody is going to come close to beating me in 2020 because of what we've done.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me now to talk more about that is New Jersey Congressman Leonard Lance. He's also on the House Energy and Commerce Committee and he questioned Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey yesterday. We'll get to that in a moment -- sir.

Congressman -- thanks very much for joining us this morning. Good to have you.

REP. LEONARD LANCE (R-NJ), HOUSE ENERGY AND COMMERCE COMMITTEE: Thank you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Your thoughts on this op-ed this morning?

LANCE: I prefer signed op-eds. And I think that the "New York Times" should have requested who actually wrote it. And I think it leads to the opinion of quite a few that we need to have specificity in this area. And I would hope that the "New York Times" might agree with that.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean at this point it's not anything different than we've heard from the President's detractors. It's more of the same. And this particular op-ed is somebody saying what we've heard from his detractors for the last year-and-a-half but unwilling to put his name to it.

LANCE: That is correct. And let me say, I have great faith in General Kelly and, for example, in General Mattis. And certainly I think that the editorial should have been signed -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: And what about great faith in President Trump -- sir? Do you have faith in him?

LANCE: I agree with the President in some of his policies. I disagree with others of his policies. But regarding the system of government we have, Maria -- we have checks and balances here in Congress. Indeed that's what's occurring at the moment in the Senate with the nomination of Judge Kavanaugh -- advice and consent.

And I believe in our system of government. And As you pointed out at the top of the hour, the economy is very strong at the moment.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about the technology CEOs and executives grilled on Capitol Hill yesterday. Twitter stock yesterday took a tumble after the House questioned CEO Jack Dorsey over bias against conservatives. You specifically asked him about the algorithm's fairness. Let's take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JACK DORSEY, CEO, TWITTER: We need to understand as we use this artificial intelligence for more and more of the things that we do that, number one, that they're unbiased outcomes; and number two, that they can explain why they made the decision in the first place.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Do you feel like you -- do you feel like you got the answers you were looking for -- Congressman?

LANCE: I think that remains to be seen. And Mr. Dorsey said Twitter would be doing a better job in the future. Was the bias intentional or unintentional? I'm not sure.

But regardless of that, there should not be bias -- Maria. And it's now the responsibility of Twitter and other companies -- Google, for example -- to make sure that there is no bias.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I know, but I mean, he's blaming the algorithms and saying we want the algorithms to be fair.

I mean we're not stupid. Algorithms don't come out of magic. Somebody programs the algorithms. Did you get at who is programming the algorithms and what they're looking at in terms of metrics to put the algorithm together?

LANCE: He was asked that. And you're obviously precisely right that this is based upon human input. And we want to make sure that human input is in no way biased against conservatives, for example.

And I do not believe Twitter has done a good job in the past. And it has to do a much better job in the future; and that was the opinion of the committee. And that is why Mr. Dorsey came before the committee.

BARTIROMO: So before we move on -- I want to ask you about the Kavanaugh hearing -- but before we move on from this, what are the potential drawbacks for the tech companies? I mean what can you actually do in terms of Congress writing a new law? What do you think plays out from this?

LANCE: Of course, we're the committee of jurisdiction for legislation. I am not there yet. I would prefer to have a situation where there doesn't need to be further legislation but that remains to be seen, Maria, based upon what these companies do in the future.

And incidentally I was disappointed that Google chose not to show up on the Senate side of the Capitol yesterday.

BARTIROMO: Now, will you subpoena Google? Where does that go in terms of Google just blowing it off?

LANCE: I think it's a decision in the Senate as to whether the Senate wishes to subpoena. And I hope regarding future invitations, Google will come in voluntarily -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Congressman -- let me switch gears, the Senate heading into day three of questioning Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh. He took a stance on respecting and enacting the law, congress decides. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JUDGE BRETT KAVANAUGH, SUPREME COURT NOMINEE: We have to stick to the laws passed by Congress. You make the policy. We'll follow the policy direction that you put into the laws that are enacted, passed by the House and Senate, signed by the President.

We don't rewrite those laws. The executive branch also shouldn't be rewriting those laws beyond the scope of the authority granted.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Do you feel, Congressman -- that you got what you needed from Kavanaugh yesterday?

LANCE: I certainly agree with Judge Kavanaugh that it's our responsibility, exclusively, to write legislation and the Supreme Court should be the umpire. It's neither the pitcher, nor the batter.

And this is also true regarding the executive branch. It shouldn't engage in action outside the scope of the statutory matters that we have enacted here on Capitol Hill.

And so I agree with Judge Kavanaugh and I think at least so far he's done a fine job before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

BARTIROMO: Now, one of the top stories in the "Wall Street Journal" this morning, the Supreme Court nominee Kavanaugh would not say whether a president could pardon himself or must comply with a subpoena. Instead, promising senators to be an independent justice, unswayed by politics. Your reaction to that?

LANCE: I think that that is the appropriate stance because it might come before him. My own opinion, and I am a lawyer, is that presidents cannot pardon themselves. But I'm not been nominated to the Supreme Court, and of course, he wants to view these matters as they may come before him in the future.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you, Congressman -- there was a lot of hysteria over the lack of documents that the Democrats wanted to see about Judge Kavanaugh. And I find it really ironic that here we have Congress on the left demanding more documents about Judge Kavanaugh and yet the Congress, the Intel Committee in particular has been asking the FBI and the DOJ for documents for a year-and-a-half and they haven't gotten those documents and we don't see that kind of hysteria there.

What is your take on what's going on in that investigation?

LANCE: I think you make a very good point and I think that Chairman Grassley is doing an excellent job and he addressed those questions on the first day. And Democratic members of the Senate Judiciary Committee have access to documents.

And I don't think this is different in substantial regard from what occurred when Justice Kagan came before the court, she of course, having been Solicitor-General.

BARTIROMO: Are you expecting Brett Kavanaugh to get confirmed?

LANCE: I think that that is highly likely to occur and of course the Senate may have a full complement, since Senator Kyl is coming back to the Senate based upon the passing of Senator McCain. And my best estimate at the moment is that Judge Kavanaugh will become Justice Kavanaugh.

BARTIROMO: And what do you want to see going into the midterms in terms of priorities for this president?

LANCE: We want to keep the economy strong. I favor bipartisanship moving forward in the new term of Congress. And in the district I serve, the question I'm asked most is let's be bipartisan.

And I'm a member of what's known at the Problem Solvers Caucus here on the House side of the capitol. And I think we should work in a bipartisan capacity moving forward. And that's what the people of the United States want -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I think you're right. So how does the Problem Solver Caucus deal with the delays that we saw at the beginning of the Kavanaugh hearing? How does the Problem Solver Caucus deal with Senator Kamala Harris who wanted to stop the whole thing even before it began?

LANCE: The Problem Solvers Caucus is here on the House side but regarding my Senate colleagues, my distinguished Senate colleagues, I thought that Chairman Grassley did a terrific job. And I don't think that Kamala Harris should have interrupted Chairman Grassley in literally his first paragraph.

BARTIROMO: Right.

LANCE: And I think that he is viewed as an incredibly fair chair. I think that all would agree with that on Capitol Hill. And I think that he is conducting an excellent hearing.

BARTIROMO: So do you think voters will react to what's happening on the left -- the constant hysteria and resist movement? Are voters going to vote against that in November?

LANCE: I think that the American people are in the sensible center, Maria, and they do not like the partisan bickering back and forth.

BARTIROMO: Right.

LANCE: I think it's much too extreme and we have to be governed in this country by the sensible center. I am a moderate conservative. And I try to work with those on the moderate liberal side.

But I don't think that we should move forward in a manner based upon constantly interrupting each other.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LANCE: I do not think that is in the best interest of the American people.

BARTIROMO: Of course. Congressman -- it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

LANCE: Thank you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Leonard Lance joining us there.

Coming up, Nike's controversial debut, it happens tonight. The backlash as the athletic company gears up to air the first ad featuring Colin Kaepernick during the NFL season kick-off game tonight.

Then calling all gamers, details on the new X-Box grease-proof controller, taking the Internet by storm. You can have your greasy chicken wings and still game.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

South Korea's special envoy saying that Kim Jong-un's trust in President Trump remains unchanged.

Cheryl Casone with the details there -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Mari.

After visiting North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, South Korean officials have said that Kim emphasized that he has never made a negative comment about President Trump. They also say that Kim wants to denuclearize his country before President Trump's current term ends in early 2021.

And they set up a summit for September 18th through the 20th -- that's going to be in Pyongyang between Kim and South Korean President Moon Jae- in. That's going to be their third meeting since April.

Meanwhile President Trump tweeted this morning, "Kim Jong-un of North Korea proclaims unwavering faith in President Trump. Thank you to Chairman Kim. We will get it done together."

Well, American Express reportedly under investigation by the FBI. "The Wall Street Journal" says that the FBI is looking into foreign exchange transactions at the company and whether the international payments department there misrepresented the pricing to the clients they were trying to get more business they say. The newspaper says the inquiry is right now in the early stages. Shares of American Express fell more than 1 percent yesterday.

Well, crypto currencies getting hammered again today. Bitcoin has fallen more than 12 percent in the last 24 hours. Some are blaming the downturn on reports that Goldman Sachs has given up on plans to create a crypto currency trading desk. But the crypto markets are prone to wild swings and flash crashes as we know by now. Bitcoin down about 8 percent at this hour, it's sitting right now at $6,398 -- $6,400 live on your screen.

And then there is this, we are soon going to know -- I mean I think we kind of know what's going to happen to Kevin Spacey's character on "House of Cards" for the sixth and final season. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROBIN WRIGHT, ACTRESS: When they bury me it won't be in my backyard. And when they pay their respects they'll have to wait in line.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Oh, yes. Robin Wright's character, Claire Underwood is standing over the grave of her husband, Frank Underwood, who was played by Spacey, of course, in we think the backyard. Killing off (INAUDIBLE) might not be as big a surprise for any of you, if you love the show. Netflix cut ties with Spacey last November after he was accused of sexual misconduct.

New season, Maria -- Netflix, November 2nd. My favorite line from the finale from last season was Claire said, "It's my turn."

BARTIROMO: Yes, that was her.

CASONE: It is.

PETE: That was her final line.

BARTIROMO: I love it. I'm excited about it. Are you still excited about it?

MCDOWELL: Robin Wright was the reason that I watched it anyway because Kevin Spacey increasingly sounded like fog horn leg horn. That was where his acting was going.

PETE: And you don't like fog horn.

MCDOWELL: Well, it's like -- it's a caricature of a southerner. "I'm Frank Underwood". You make Jeff Sessions sound like he's from south Boston.

BARTIROMO: I'm excited about this. November 2nd. Ok, we're going to watch that.

Meanwhile, we've got this -- breaking news, Vice President Pence's chief of staff is tweeting out this denial after speculation that Pence may have had a hand in the anonymous op-ed. Here's what he's writing. Jarrod AGen says "The Vice President puts his name on his op-eds. The 'New York Times' should be ashamed and so should the person who wrote the false, illogical and gutless op-ed. Our office is above such amateur acts."

We will take a break. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: All right. More reaction, President Trump is tweeting again this morning. He says this right now, "The deep state and the left and their vehicle, the fake news media, are going crazy and they don't know what to do. The economy is booming like never before. Jobs are at historic highs. Soon two Supreme Court justices and maybe declassification to find additional corruption. Wow."

That's my take on it, for sure. That's why I think this op-ed is coming out now, because he's having too many successes.

Meanwhile, the NFL season kicks off tonight amid more controversy. Jared Max is here with those details. Jared -- good morning to you.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTS: Another wow.

Colin Kaepernick hasn't been a football player since 2016, but he may be the most talked about figure we will see during tonight's season opener between the Super Bowl champion Eagles and Atlanta Falcons.

Yesterday Kaepernick shared a new Nike commercial that will air during NBC's broadcast tonight. It's narrated by and features the athlete turned activist.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

COLIN KAEPERNICK, FORMER NFL PLAYER: So don't ask if your dreams are crazy. Ask if they're crazy enough.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: Don't ask if you're crazy; ask if you're crazy enough. In this two minute ad, Kaepernick narrates inspirational blurbs about athletes who overcame unfavorable odds to achieve unprecedented athletic greatness. And then he gets tight into the message.

You remember Nate Boyer -- a veteran Green Beret, served multiple tours in Iraq and Afghanistan. A former NFL player convinced Kaepernick two years ago to kneel instead of sitting. There's never been a negative connotation to taking a knee before.

He took issue with Colin's Nike ad for saying he sacrificed everything. He says "It's dangerous territory to suggest something like that. For me when I hear sacrifice everything, the last thing I think about is money. If it's a matter of sacrificing money or your brand, that's far different than sacrificing your life.

One of the athletes featured in the Nike ad, linebacker Shaquem Griffin, who had his left hand amputated when he was a young child, a result of pregnancy complications. Now, a rook, he will be making his first start, named a starter for the Seahawks against the Broncos, Sunday.

Tennis anyone? Novak Djokovic entered the semifinals at the U.S. Open. Last night Novak defeated John Millman, the guy who beat Federer in straight sets. So he will face K. Nishikori in the semis.

American Madison Keys also won which means we are on course for a possible all-American women's final between Keys and Serena Williams. The women's semis are today.

Did you ever see a home run hit 505 feet? Trevor Story of the (INAUDIBLE) leading Colorado Rockies last night hit three. This one traveled further than any homer since Statcast began to track them three years ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Trevor Story, one more than Arenado has 94 now with the two home runs tonight. And then Story (INAUDIBLE) -- how about number three? Are you kidding me?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: Trevor Story -- what a story. Rockies lead the NOS (ph) by two.

BARTIROMO: Good stories today -- Jared.

MCDOWELL: I was clapping for Shaqueam Griffin.

(CROSSTALK)

MAX: Yes, awesome stories.

MCDOWELL: He plays with his brother Shaquill Griffin. And I noted his performance during the NFL combine and predicted that he would get drafted by the Seahawks.

MAX: He's playing (ph) with a prosthetic hand.

BARTIROMO: Well, the game should be interesting tonight with the new Nike ad. In my opinion, the people who are sacrificing everything are the people who are going to fight for the freedoms of America.

MAX: Yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Those people who actually decide --

PETE: Hear, hear.

BARTIROMO: -- to sacrifice things and go fight in Afghanistan, in Iran, and everywhere else in the Middle East, Iraq. I mean, it's ridiculous to say he sacrificed everything.

MAX: I also thing it was ridiculous that he got tied into this ad talking about athletes. I don't know where he fits in. And for my money it seemed like they completely ripped off a beautiful commercial that was made by Apple over 20 years ago with the whole "to the crazy ones campaign". I mean to me I'm like is this plagiarized?

MCDOWELL: You used the right word, commercial. This is, as I said earlier this week, this is a business calculation. They did the risk-reward analysis. "The Wall Street Journal" actually wrote a great herd (ph) on the Street about it, that Nike is worried about losing its cultural relevancy.

They don't care about older customers. They're trying to be progressive and about new customers and about choosing controversy over obscurity.

MAX: I guess they figure they could fool the younger audience. I don't know. I don't know where he's --

BARTIROMO: Colin Kaepernick --

PETE: They're targeting 17 and 19 year-olds or whatever who like disruption, who like this idea of being very challenging. My view is, they could have selected, to your point a vet who has an amputated leg and who is participating in the various kinds of special Olympics and so forth.

I mean I think there are so many alternatives that could have fit their bill --

(CROSSTALK)

PETE: -- and not divided their customer base because that's what this is going to do.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Colin Kaepernick should join the military.

MAX: He should join something and start to speak.

MCDOWELL: Well, Adidas overnight gained. Nike's sales went down three out of the last four quarters. That's why they're doing it because we're still sitting here talking about it.

BARTIROMO: That's true. Thank you -- Jared Max.

All right. Catch Jared's sports reports on FOX NEWS HEADLINES 24/7" or on Sirius Radio, XM115.

Coming up, the future of Uber. We're going to hear from the ride-hailing app's CEO. It's a "First on Fox Business" interview outlining his plan to take the company public. Dara Khosrowshahi is with Susan Li.

Plus, forget napkins, the grease-proof X-Box controller taking the Internet by storm coming up.

BARTIROMO: Good Thursday morning. Welcome back everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, September 6th. Your top stories right now, 07:32 a.m. on the East Coast.

Uber safe, the ride sharing company announcing safety features for passengers and drivers. The CEO also saying that the company's goal is to completely replace your car.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DARA KHOSROWSHAHI, CEO, UBER: You own a car to get to work. You own a car to pick up the kids at school. You own a car to get groceries, etcetera.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Right.

KHOSROWSHAHI: And we're building out services to solve each of those use cases and ultimately make it -- make it unnecessary for you to own a car.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We will have more from our first on Fox Business interview in just a few minutes. Futures this morning showing the markets will open mixed this morning. Take a look at where we're looking. The Dow Industrials up about 20 points today, S&P 500 up a quarter point, but the NASDAQ is negative going into the open, two hours away.

After a mixed day on Wall Street yesterday, markets as you can see were fractionally moving with the Dow up 22, S&P down eight, but the NASDAQ was the big story as the technology executives testified on Capitol Hill, the NASDAQ was down better than one percent.

In Europe this morning, mixed story there. FT-100 down 12 points, CAC Quarante up 13 and the DAX Index in Germany up 15.

Checking the Asian markets finishing lower overnight across the board, the worst performer Hong Kong. Hang Seng Index down about one percent.

Well, he is out. Former Louisville coach Rick Pitino says he's done with coaching nearly a year after his ouster. We'll have him here live with us in just a few minutes to talk about that and his new book this morning.

Making the grade. The Wall Street journal out with its definitive list of the best colleges. You've got to see this list, who came out on top, coming up.

And don't stop playing, this new controller promises to stay grease-free so you can keep the game going and eat your greasy chicken wings. All those stories coming up this Thursday morning.

But first, the future of Uber. In a first time Fox Business interview, Uber's CEO is speaking out on the path for the ride hailing company to go public. Susan Li got the exclusive interview and she's here with the details, Susan.

LI: Good morning to you. So, 2019 seems to be on track for one of the largest IPOs in the world. Uber valued at close to $70 billion. And of course, I had to ask Dara Khosrowshahi if he is indeed going public next year.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LI: People want to know, are you still sticking with your time line of an IPO in the back half of 2019? Because your new CFO who will start in a few days.

KHOSROWSHAHI: Nelson, he's starting next week.

LI: Yes, he says he's not on-board yet though for 2019 listing.

KHOSROWSHAHI: I would expect nothing less of Nelson. He's independent- minded. He's rigorous. And so far he's on the outside. So I think, I absolutely want Nelson to come in and I think that when he sees all of the work that the teams are doing, I think that he will agree that we are ready for a 2019 IPO.

LI: Right.

KHOSROWSHAHI: There's a bunch of system for that going on, financial work that's going on. The company is big enough. The company is incredibly important to the world.

LI: Right.

KHOSROWSHAHI: And we have some incredibly talented technologists out there. So, I think we're going to be ready but I absolutely want that stamp of approval from the CFO.

LI: Yes, there's always a but.

KHOSROWSHAHI: Yes.

LI: Lyft wants to also IPO in March or April next year.

KHOSROWSHAHI: So we hear, yes.

LI: And the thinking on the street is if they IPO before you, they basically take up all the IPO capital in the market. Are you concerned?

KHOSROWSHAHI: I'm not concerned. Listen, this is Lyft and ourselves are part of a transportation revolution. This is about ultimately ending car ownership.

The transportation market is a $6 trillion business. You may think that Uber is big but we're $50 billion. We account for less than one percent of miles driven and really what ourselves and Lyft are trying to do is to break apart all the use cases of owning a car. You own a car to get to work. You own a car to pick up the kids at school. You own a car to get groceries, etcetera.

LI: Right.

KHOSROWSHAHI: And we're building out services to solve each of those use cases and ultimately make it -- make it unnecessary for you to own a car. And we think there are plenty of companies who can be a part of that revolution.

LI: Right.

KHOSROWSHAHI: And I think investors are going to line up behind us and Lyft. I certainly hope they are.

LI: So you're guaranteeing a 2019 IPO?

KHOSROWSHAHI: There's no guarantee. You don't know what the market is doing. LI: 80 percent?

KHOSROWSHAHI: I can guarantee you that we'll be ready and we want to -- and hopefully, the markets will be ready for us.

LI: So, you talked about how big Uber is in the ride hailing services. Some say you own 73 percent of the market. Given that the U.S. President has talked about anti-trust situation with the big tech companies like Google, Amazon, and Facebook. Do you think that big tech companies like Uber might be regulated in the future? Might be broken up?

KHOSROWSHAHI: Well, we're regulated -- listen, we're regulated now, right?

LI: Right.

KHOSROWSHAHI: We work in every single city etcetera. We look at the market as the $6 trillion transportation market. We're tiny, tiny, tiny part of the market. We account for less than one percent of miles driven on the road.

LI: Right.

KHOSROWSHAHI: So, I think Uber can be ultimately 20, 30 times bigger than it is today.

LI: So, no fear of being broken up at all?

KHOSROWSHAHI: No fear of being broken up. And listen, I think that ultimately regulators are our partners.

LI: Talking to our audience, you know, there's been a lot of concern about political bias in Silicon Valley. You're a giant, your respectable voice in Silicon Valley. So, I have to ask you this question. President Trump thinks that there's a liberal bias in Silicon Valley with big tech companies. Employees and big tech companies have said that they feel that their conservative voices have been silenced. Do you think that's true?

KHOSROWSHAHI: I guarantee you that your wait times for your Uber are going to be equal whether you're Republican or not or Democrat. I don't think -- listen, I think that bias sees -- if there's a bias, I don't think that it is a bias on purpose.

We as a -- as a company, as a leadership team have been trained on bias as we're -- as well. And there's some implicit biases that you may not be aware of as a person and I think awareness is step one. So, I don't think that there's any bias on purpose but if you have a bunch of like-minded people building product, you may get product that's shaped in one way or the other.

That's why for example, from our standpoint, we want to have more women, we want to have more under-represented people working as engineers and product people and have representation at all parts of our company so that the products that we're building reflect our driver partners and our rider partners and aren't with any biases that we're not aware of.

So, listen, we're human. All of us are vulnerable. I think that all of these companies are trying to do the right thing but they've got some learning to do and I think the way that they operate going forward has to change.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Great interview. And we will be showing you more of that interview of Susan's throughout the day. And Susan, I thought it was really interesting that he's talking about this company potentially getting 20 to 30 times bigger.

LI: Yes, you imagine that Uber valued at close to 70 billion. He was under selling himself a little bit. That's a really huge company. But there's just so much more potential because we're doing a lot of things, not just ride hailing. You know, they're n to flying taxis which he says will be around in five years, believe it or not.

BARTIROMO: That's funny.

LI: Yes, autonomous vehicles, they're still spending a lot of money trying to develop self-driving cars. And I would say that yes, they're just thinking of different ways, like scooters and bikes in the future as well. So it's not just cars. And he doesn't think you need to own your own car or your own transportation.

MCDOWELL: It's also his personality though, and the fact that people do love working for this guy.

LI: They love him.

MCDOWELL: When he talks about women that's very important. Because under Travis Kalanick, the founder of Uber.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It was common knowledge that for women it was a hostile work environment. We've learned more detail about exactly what was going on there in recent years. Nevertheless, they couldn't hide -- no woman wanted to go work there.

LI: But there was accusations of misogyny.

MCDOWELL: Right.

LI: And also sexual harassment claims as well. But I covered him at Expedia. He was Expedia's CEO for 10 years, most loved, most liked, most respected, charismatic man, and he's brought that to Uber. Because after the presentation when he went downstairs after all the interviews, a big round of applause. And I -- it's rare --

BARTIROMO: Wow.

LI: -- in the corporate world. And he's just a likable guy. They just want to rally for him.

BARTIROMO: They've got new features, an emergency button fro drivers.

LI: That's right. So, they were here in New York in the Midtown Manhattan event to launch their new safety features for passengers and riders. So, it's something called ride check in the feature. If you're on a ride, they will basically use the sensors off your smartphone to detect if you've been in an accident, if it takes longer than usual. If you're making extra stops, just to make sure everyone's OK.

They'll also mask your location, your pick-up and drop-off locations and your phone numbers to make sure no one else has access to that information. Because as a woman or anyone really riding, you want to be safe at the end of the day, right?

BARTIROMO: Of course, that's number one. Susa, great interview.

LI: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for bringing that to us. Susan Li there.

Coming up, Hall of Fame basketball coach Rick Pitino will join us. He'll discuss life off the basketball court. And why he's done coaching, he says, that's coming up.

Then, ranking your college education. We're revealing the university that came out on top this year. You'll want to see this list, next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Trucks abandoned as a wildfire rages around a California highway. Cheryl Casone with the details. What a scene, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, you thought these fires were over, Maria. This is the Delta fire. It just erupted yesterday afternoon. It's burned through nearly eight square miles of timber and brush on both sides of Interstate five. All of this is just north of Redding, Northern California.

Now, according to California Highway Patrol, about 17 semitrailers have been left behind at this point. You can see some of that video there. At least four of them had caught fire. The drivers were able to evacuate safely.

Well, CBS reportedly is holding talks with its majority shareholder, Shari Redstone National Amusements over which company should gain control of the broadcast network. Sources are telling the Wall Street Journal that the talks come less than a month before the dispute has to go to trial. After CBS led by Les Moonves sued National Amusements in an attempt to lower its stake in the company in CBS.

Redstone currently controls about 79 percent of CBS. The stock is down about 10 percent so far this year.

Well, Harvard University taking the top spot in the Wall Street Journal times higher education college rankings for the second straight year. The rankings indicate how well colleges prepare students for life after graduation. MIT came in second place after Harvard, followed by Yale, Columbia and California Institute of technology. That rounded out the top five.

Running down the list by the way, the top 10, Stanford, Brown and Duke tied for seventh place. Followed by Princeton and the University of Pennsylvania.

All right. Good news for you gamers out there. Xbox is coming out with a grease-proof controller. Now you can eat that bucket of chicken, that greasy pizza, those chicken wings without worrying about ruining your device. Unfortunately, this is only being offered for limited edition in Australia. It's part of a marketing campaign for the game PlayerUnknown's Battleground. So if you're not in Australia, you can always put order the official Xbox one wireless controller, that's hitting shelves October 30th. But we've the grease of chicken on the side. Shares of Sony, which makes the Xbox, up 23 percent so far this year, Maria. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, good to know that. Thanks so much.

CASONE: Yes, it's important information.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly.

ROSCHELLE: You need a dog-proof one too. Often eaten by dogs.

MCDOWELL: No, they step on it.

ROSCHELLE: I step on them. The dog chews on them.

LIZ PEEK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I'd like to see the grease accumulator on some of the ones that have come back. I mean that's really the interesting sort of data point, right? What do they look like?

BARTIROMO: Coming up, Hall of Fame basketball coach Rick Pitino is here. He'll discuss his new book Life Off the basketball court and why he's done with coaching. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Life off of the court, former Louisville Cardinals men's basketball coach Rick Pitino is out with a new book. Documenting his coaching career and the recruiting scandal which shook college basketball, you may remember.

Joining us now is Hall of Fame basketball coach and the author of Pitino, My Story, Rick Pitino. Rick, great to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

RICK PITINO, HALL OF FAME BASKETBALL COACH, UNIVERSITY OF LOUISVILLE: Well, thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: And you said you recently -- you were done with coaching. Let's start there, what led to that decision?

PITINO: Well, a lot of thought. I love coaching. The passion of it, love being on the sidelines, just worship March Madness. I just think that's about the greatest month in all sports. But I realized that after the Southern District of New York put my name in a complaint and involved me with something I was totally foreign to, it would be unfair for any college to hire me. Because you start out at a press conference, the colleges all excited to have you, the student bodies all excited and then they bring up two scandals. So, I think it's best to close the book on that and to get on with something else that's stimulating in my life.

BARTIROMO: Can you walk us through how that felt for you? Tell us about the scandal and what happened.

PITINO: Well, all of a sudden my two assistant coaches are picked up by the FBI and then they come and visit me and said do you want an attorney present. I said, for what? They explained to me what happened. And basically, this has been going on since 2014. They -- somebody was indicted. A scam artist, of which some very, very serious things that have happened to him. He was a scam artist and he said I can deliver college basketball coaches to you who are doing it the wrong way. And like they all do, he turned in some people. And then four years later after a lot of FISA warrants would a lot of investigative work by the FBI, and the talented men of the FBI. I don't think they should be dealing with college basketball assistants.

They've come away after four years with indicting four assistant coaches. A couple Adidas representatives, an AAU coach that took money but they exonerated him because he kept the money, he didn't give it to a prospect.

And meanwhile, my life has been shaken. And I'm out of -- I'm out of my passion. But the worst part about the whole thing, because I sent my lawyers in to visit with them and tell them that I've never cheated in a game of college basketball. I've never cheated the game itself. I've just given a lot to the game, I believe.

And their response was interesting, it's look, you damaged this man's life, his credibility, worked 40 years in the game. And their response very callously was we deal with collateral damage all the time.

So, I'm waiting for the phone call from them, apologizing. And everybody says you're going to wait until you die because it's not happening.

ROSCHELLE: Coach, there's been a lot of talk about potentially paying college athletes not just basketball players, would that alleviate some of the noise that's in the system?

PITINO: You know it's -- the problem is, I believe in paying the athletes, letting them -- by paying -- if I'm a great athlete, I want to do a commercial, I have the right to do a commercial. The problem with that is then cheating comes into that area. OK, if I'm school X and I want to do a car commercial. We'll give you $60,000 instead of the other school giving you $20,000.

So, it's a difficult way to navigate through what to do, what not to do. I believe one thing, though. If parents want to go see their child play and you're making millions of dollars off that young man's athleticism, they should be able to have their flights and hotel paid for to go see that young man play, especially during March Madness in the tournament. Every game those parents should be able to be put up in a hotel and if flights should be paid for.

MCDOWELL: Well, you said it was unfair to colleges if they took you on as a coach because of -- it would expose them to the allegations. But has anybody really approached you? Have you -- did you get phone calls from other colleges or even professional teams?

PITINO: I had two job offers last year. We talked. We sat down. One president came in and was nice enough to visit with me. And then there was another school, I was interested in --

MCDOWELL: Do you want to tell us which schools?

PITINO: I'd rather not. But the other school I was -- I was interested in. They called the NCAA and said, can you give us clearance on Rick Pitino, he did nothing wrong. Their response to us, we can't investigate anything until the Southern District of New York is done with their -- with whatever they're doing.

BARTIROMO: So what, do you have a time line in terms of when they're done? Are they done at this point?

PITINO: I don't know. I know there's some things are going to trial yet in September. Nobody from Louisville, not myself. I'm not involved in any way. And I have no fears about any of that because I know what I've done with college basketball and I know what I believe in my beliefs in doing it the right way and we do it like most coaches.

By the way, I believe that less than 10 percent of college basketball is corrupt. I think 90 percent of college basketball, people do it the right way, their hearts are with the student athletes. They want to help those young men prosper in life.

But like any industry, whether it's Wall Street, whether it's the medical professional, less than 10 percent does it the wrong way.

BARTIROMO: Right.

PITINO: And that's what needs to be cleaned up.

BARTIROMO: Sure, we're going to be watching that Rick. Thanks so much for joining us, telling us your story.

PITINO: Thanks for having me.

MCDOWELL: Good luck.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you coach.

PITINO: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Rick Pitino there.

Still ahead, a major shift for Burberry, the changes headed to the luxury goods maker. Next hour right here, MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Thursday to you. It is Thursday September 6th. Your top stories right now just after 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

That's why for example, from our standpoint, we want to have more women, we want to have more under-represented people working as engineers and product people and have representation at all parts of our company so that the products that we're building reflect our driver partners and our rider partners and aren't with any biases that we're not aware of.

So, listen, we're human. All of us are vulnerable. I think that all of these companies are trying to do the right thing but they've got some learning to do and I think the way that they operate going forward has to change.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Great interview. And we will be showing you more of that interview of Susan's throughout the day. And Susan, I thought it was really interesting that he's talking about this company potentially getting 20 to 30 times bigger.

LI: Yes, you imagine that Uber valued at close to 70 billion. He was under selling himself a little bit. That's a really huge company. But there's just so much more potential because we're doing a lot of things, not just ride hailing. You know, they're n to flying taxis which he says will be around in five years, believe it or not.

BARTIROMO: That's funny.

LI: Yes, autonomous vehicles, they're still spending a lot of money trying to develop self-driving cars. And I would say that yes, they're just thinking of different ways, like scooters and bikes in the future as well. So it's not just cars. And he doesn't think you need to own your own car or your own transportation.

MCDOWELL: It's also his personality though, and the fact that people do love working for this guy.

LI: They love him.

MCDOWELL: When he talks about women that's very important. Because under Travis Kalanick, the founder of Uber.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It was common knowledge that for women it was a hostile work environment. We've learned more detail about exactly what was going on there in recent years. Nevertheless, they couldn't hide -- no woman wanted to go work there.

LI: But there was accusations of misogyny.

MCDOWELL: Right.

LI: And also sexual harassment claims as well. But I covered him at Expedia. He was Expedia's CEO for 10 years, most loved, most liked, most respected, charismatic man, and he's brought that to Uber. Because after the presentation when he went downstairs after all the interviews, a big round of applause. And I -- it's rare --

BARTIROMO: Wow.

LI: -- in the corporate world. And he's just a likable guy. They just want to rally for him.

BARTIROMO: They've got new features, an emergency button fro drivers.

LI: That's right. So, they were here in New York in the Midtown Manhattan event to launch their new safety features for passengers and riders. So, it's something called ride check in the feature. If you're on a ride, they will basically use the sensors off your smartphone to detect if you've been in an accident, if it takes longer than usual. If you're making extra stops, just to make sure everyone's OK.

They'll also mask your location, your pick-up and drop-off locations and your phone numbers to make sure no one else has access to that information. Because as a woman or anyone really riding, you want to be safe at the end of the day, right?

BARTIROMO: Of course, that's number one. Susa, great interview.

LI: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for bringing that to us. Susan Li there.

Coming up, Hall of Fame basketball coach Rick Pitino will join us. He'll discuss life off the basketball court. And why he's done coaching, he says, that's coming up.

Then, ranking your college education. We're revealing the university that came out on top this year. You'll want to see this list, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Trucks abandoned as a wildfire rages around a California highway. Cheryl Casone with the details. What a scene, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, you thought these fires were over, Maria. This is the Delta fire. It just erupted yesterday afternoon. It's burned through nearly eight square miles of timber and brush on both sides of Interstate five. All of this is just north of Redding, Northern California.

Now, according to California Highway Patrol, about 17 semitrailers have been left behind at this point. You can see some of that video there. At least four of them had caught fire. The drivers were able to evacuate safely.

Well, CBS reportedly is holding talks with its majority shareholder, Shari Redstone National Amusements over which company should gain control of the broadcast network. Sources are telling the Wall Street Journal that the talks come less than a month before the dispute has to go to trial. After CBS led by Les Moonves sued National Amusements in an attempt to lower its stake in the company in CBS.

Redstone currently controls about 79 percent of CBS. The stock is down about 10 percent so far this year.

Well, Harvard University taking the top spot in the Wall Street Journal times higher education college rankings for the second straight year. The rankings indicate how well colleges prepare students for life after graduation. MIT came in second place after Harvard, followed by Yale, Columbia and California Institute of technology. That rounded out the top five.

Running down the list by the way, the top 10, Stanford, Brown and Duke tied for seventh place. Followed by Princeton and the University of Pennsylvania.

All right. Good news for you gamers out there. Xbox is coming out with a grease-proof controller. Now you can eat that bucket of chicken, that greasy pizza, those chicken wings without worrying about ruining your device. Unfortunately, this is only being offered for limited edition in Australia. It's part of a marketing campaign for the game PlayerUnknown's Battleground. So if you're not in Australia, you can always put order the official Xbox one wireless controller, that's hitting shelves October 30th. But we've the grease of chicken on the side. Shares of Sony, which makes the Xbox, up 23 percent so far this year, Maria. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, good to know that. Thanks so much.

CASONE: Yes, it's important information.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly.

ROSCHELLE: You need a dog-proof one too. Often eaten by dogs.

MCDOWELL: No, they step on it.

ROSCHELLE: I step on them. The dog chews on them.

LIZ PEEK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I'd like to see the grease accumulator on some of the ones that have come back. I mean that's really the interesting sort of data point, right? What do they look like?

BARTIROMO: Coming up, Hall of Fame basketball coach Rick Pitino is here. He'll discuss his new book Life Off the basketball court and why he's done with coaching. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Life off of the court, former Louisville Cardinals men's basketball coach Rick Pitino is out with a new book. Documenting his coaching career and the recruiting scandal which shook college basketball, you may remember.

Joining us now is Hall of Fame basketball coach and the author of Pitino, My Story, Rick Pitino. Rick, great to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

RICK PITINO, HALL OF FAME BASKETBALL COACH, UNIVERSITY OF LOUISVILLE: Well, thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: And you said you recently -- you were done with coaching. Let's start there, what led to that decision?

PITINO: Well, a lot of thought. I love coaching. The passion of it, love being on the sidelines, just worship March Madness. I just think that's about the greatest month in all sports. But I realized that after the Southern District of New York put my name in a complaint and involved me with something I was totally foreign to, it would be unfair for any college to hire me. Because you start out at a press conference, the colleges all excited to have you, the student bodies all excited and then they bring up two scandals. So, I think it's best to close the book on that and to get on with something else that's stimulating in my life.

BARTIROMO: Can you walk us through how that felt for you? Tell us about the scandal and what happened.

PITINO: Well, all of a sudden my two assistant coaches are picked up by the FBI and then they come and visit me and said do you want an attorney present. I said, for what? They explained to me what happened. And basically, this has been going on since 2014. They -- somebody was indicted. A scam artist, of which some very, very serious things that have happened to him. He was a scam artist and he said I can deliver college basketball coaches to you who are doing it the wrong way. And like they all do, he turned in some people. And then four years later after a lot of FISA warrants would a lot of investigative work by the FBI, and the talented men of the FBI. I don't think they should be dealing with college basketball assistants.

They've come away after four years with indicting four assistant coaches. A couple Adidas representatives, an AAU coach that took money but they exonerated him because he kept the money, he didn't give it to a prospect.

And meanwhile, my life has been shaken. And I'm out of -- I'm out of my passion. But the worst part about the whole thing, because I sent my lawyers in to visit with them and tell them that I've never cheated in a game of college basketball. I've never cheated the game itself. I've just given a lot to the game, I believe.

And their response was interesting, it's look, you damaged this man's life, his credibility, worked 40 years in the game. And their response very callously was we deal with collateral damage all the time.

So, I'm waiting for the phone call from them, apologizing. And everybody says you're going to wait until you die because it's not happening.

ROSCHELLE: Coach, there's been a lot of talk about potentially paying college athletes not just basketball players, would that alleviate some of the noise that's in the system?

PITINO: You know it's -- the problem is, I believe in paying the athletes, letting them -- by paying -- if I'm a great athlete, I want to do a commercial, I have the right to do a commercial. The problem with that is then cheating comes into that area. OK, if I'm school X and I want to do a car commercial. We'll give you $60,000 instead of the other school giving you $20,000.

So, it's a difficult way to navigate through what to do, what not to do. I believe one thing, though. If parents want to go see their child play and you're making millions of dollars off that young man's athleticism, they should be able to have their flights and hotel paid for to go see that young man play, especially during March Madness in the tournament. Every game those parents should be able to be put up in a hotel and if flights should be paid for.

MCDOWELL: Well, you said it was unfair to colleges if they took you on as a coach because of -- it would expose them to the allegations. But has anybody really approached you? Have you -- did you get phone calls from other colleges or even professional teams?

PITINO: I had two job offers last year. We talked. We sat down. One president came in and was nice enough to visit with me. And then there was another school, I was interested in --

MCDOWELL: Do you want to tell us which schools?

PITINO: I'd rather not. But the other school I was -- I was interested in. They called the NCAA and said, can you give us clearance on Rick Pitino, he did nothing wrong. Their response to us, we can't investigate anything until the Southern District of New York is done with their -- with whatever they're doing.

BARTIROMO: So what, do you have a time line in terms of when they're done? Are they done at this point?

PITINO: I don't know. I know there's some things are going to trial yet in September. Nobody from Louisville, not myself. I'm not involved in any way. And I have no fears about any of that because I know what I've done with college basketball and I know what I believe in my beliefs in doing it the right way and we do it like most coaches.

By the way, I believe that less than 10 percent of college basketball is corrupt. I think 90 percent of college basketball, people do it the right way, their hearts are with the student athletes. They want to help those young men prosper in life.

But like any industry, whether it's Wall Street, whether it's the medical professional, less than 10 percent does it the wrong way.

BARTIROMO: Right.

PITINO: And that's what needs to be cleaned up.

BARTIROMO: Sure, we're going to be watching that Rick. Thanks so much for joining us, telling us your story.

PITINO: Thanks for having me.

MCDOWELL: Good luck.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you coach.

PITINO: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Rick Pitino there.

Still ahead, a major shift for Burberry, the changes headed to the luxury goods maker. Next hour right here, MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Thursday to you. It is Thursday September 6th. Your top stories right now just after 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

urn:contentItem:5YV0-JX21-F021-60VC-00000-00Resist temptation. The herd isn't always right.2020-05-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:40ZLexisNexisResist temptation. The herd isn't always right.Nilushi Karunaratne

The 'corona crunch' has decimated the stock market in an unprecedented manner. A bear market is difficult to navigate at the best of times, let alone during a global pandemic. At times of uncertainty, it can be easy for investors to get caught up in a herd mentality, following others for direction and reassurance. Surely, if the share price is on its way up at a time like this, you're onto a winner? But herein lies the danger of the bandwagon. You could be joining a run that has already taken place or extending a stretched valuation.

As we look out across the wasteland, certain companies are standing tall or getting even taller - seeming winners from the trends and changes in behaviour that Covid-19 has brought about. It's hard to ignore the excitement, from the prospect of the next generation of antiviral therapies to the technology that will underpin our increasingly digitalised lives. But before being overrun by the hype, it's worth stepping back, unpacking these hot stocks and asking: are they really smart investments?

The race for a cure

Investing in pharmaceuticals often feels akin to gambling, betting on what will be the next blockbuster drug. To give a sense of the odds, a study by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) estimates just 14 per cent of drugs developed achieve regulatory approval. Treatments take years to progress from research and development to commercial availability. As we look to conquer the novel coronavirus, that process is being condensed into just months. The urgency stems from the fact that an effective therapy could see restrictions on movement eased, while a vaccine could allow us to resume our normal lives.

Think tank the Milken Institute is tracking 199 treatments in consideration and 123 vaccines in development. But one drug, in particular, has captured the investment community's attention - Gilead Sciences' (US:GILD) remdesivir. Previously tested as an Ebola treatment, it seeks to disrupt a virus's replication process. Enjoying a first-mover advantage, it is further down the pipeline as a Covid-19 therapy than rival drugs, already being evaluated in multiple late-stage clinical studies.

But the frenzy has seen it become the tail that wags the US stock market. Its share price tracked largely sideways across 2019, but is up almost a quarter so far this year. Volatility over the past month demonstrates how investors are putting too much stock in complex medical data they do not fully understand - everybody is an armchair epidemiologist these days. For example, a summary of a Chinese trial accidentally published by the World Health Organisation (WHO) sent Gilead and the S&P 500 tumbling after revealing remdesivir had no "statistically significant clinical benefits" for Covid-19 patients. Had those eager bears awaited full publication in The Lancet, they would have seen only 237 out of a desired 453 patients were recruited as the outbreak came under control in China, making the result less conclusive.

While remdesivir has been granted 'emergency use authorisation' (EUA) by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), we would still advise caution. President Trump's favoured chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine - before he got side-tracked by disinfectant and ultraviolet light - have also been awarded EUA despite thinner clinical evidence. Meanwhile, analysts have questioned how Gilead will monetise remdesivir having spent $50m on research and development in the first quarter. RBC Capital Markets believes it will likely be provided at cost during the pandemic with profit coming from future stockpiling. This could be scuppered by an alternative treatment or vaccine.

Rather than falling victim to the breathless Gilead news cycle, we think investors should look at more diversified pharma investments exposed to the fight against coronavirus. This includes AstraZeneca (AZN) as well as GlaxoSmithKline (GSK). GSK has teamed up with French giant Sanofi (FRA:SAN) to develop a Covid-19 vaccine using its 'adjuvant' technology. Aside from this, GSK is investing heavily in research and development to bolster its pipeline, focusing on oncology treatments.

A cleaner world?

As we dedicate more of our lives standing over the sink and washing our hands, soap has never been more popular. The increased focus on personal and home hygiene has seen soaring demand for cleaning products from consumer goods specialists such as Reckitt Benckiser (RB.). Intuitively, it makes sense to think this company would do well out of this crisis - people need disinfectant, and at times of crisis they turn to trusted brands such as Harpic and Dettol. The bullish outlook on Reckitt's pandemic prospects has seen its share price recover all losses from the wider market sell-off in March.

Recent figures would seem to support this confidence. Reckitt saw a 13 per cent increase in like-for-like hygiene sales to £1.36bn in the first quarter of this year. With Lysol sales up over 50 per cent, North American hygiene revenue rose by a fifth. Strong demand for Dettol across developed and emerging markets boosted 'other' health sales by 17 per cent to £825m. In contrast to companies issuing profit warnings and scrapping their guidance, the group now anticipates a full-year performance ahead of previous expectations, although this will be tempered by higher operating costs.

Clearly, Reckitt is benefiting in the here and now. The question is whether this will last. The group concedes that "the split between defensive buying and higher levels of underlying consumption is unclear". On balance, we are likely to see more permanent changes in consumer behaviour as people (hopefully) remain more hygiene conscious moving forward. But once lockdown measures and supply chain pressures ease, consumers will once again have full access to cheaper private label substitutes that were challenging premium brands pre-pandemic - coronavirus may have granted a temporary reprieve amid panic buying and stockpiling. With this in mind, part of Reckitt's three-year transformation strategy is to invest in increasing its competitiveness. As it continues to recover from the body blow of the Mead Johnson infant formula acquisition, we think the herd is moving in the right direction with this one.

Investors looking to clean up might also consider infection prevention specialist Tristel(TSTL). Seeing a mere seven-day blip in mid-March, the shares have continued their ascent. While its chlorine dioxide products are in high demand from hospitals right now, it is more than just an opportunistic play. There were already long-term growth drivers pre-pandemic, including rising anti-microbial resistance, regulatory tailwinds and plans for US expansion.

Technology's unstoppable rise

The technology revolution has been accelerated by Covid-19. Microsoft (US:MSFT) chief executive Satya Nadella recently remarked: "We have seen two years' worth of digital transformation in two months." But it is not just 'Big Tech' reaping the benefits. Zoom Video Communications (US:ZM) has emerged as a standout player enabling businesses to stay connected during the mass work from home experiment. It has also morphed into a social network as everyday consumers use the platform for everything from family catch-ups to weddings.

With the number of daily meeting participants soaring from 10m in December to over 300m in April, the 'Zoom boom' hasn't gone unnoticed - its shares have more than doubled since the beginning of the year, reaching $143. That meteoric rise brings temptation to buy in for fear of missing out. Some investors were left red-faced after piling onto the wrong Zoom. Shares in Chinese telecommunications company Zoom Technologies (ZOOM) rocketed up from around $3 to $21 in March. The US securities and exchange commission (SEC) temporarily paused trading of that Zoom amid the confusion.

Beyond this comical error, investors in the actual Zoom have also been caught out. The newfound fame has brought increased scrutiny, unveiling a string of security and privacy concerns, from sending users' data to Facebook (US:FB) - something that has triggered a class action lawsuit in California - to account details being distributed by hackers. A report by technology and security research group Citizen Lab concluded the platform might be appropriate for social use but is "not suited for secrets". The biggest controversy is perhaps 'Zoombombing', whereby uninvited people gate-crash meetings and insert graphic, inappropriate content.

Having unveiled a new security update, Zoom contends its missteps are the growing pains of an application designed for enterprise use rather than socialising - 80 per cent of its revenue comes from business customers. Chief executive Eric Yuan says the broader usership is "presenting us with challenges we did not anticipate when the platform was conceived". That excuse isn't flying with some. Google and SpaceX, among others, have prohibited employees from using the app and there is mounting pressure from US lawmakers for the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to launch an investigation.

Zoom's financial performance is less controversial. Unlike some other tech unicorns that have floated, it is profitable. It registered a pre-tax profit of $26.4m in the 12 months to 31 January, up from $8.3m a year earlier, on the back of an 88 per cent increase in revenue to $623m. It also generated $114m of free cash flow.

Analysts are split on how the pandemic will play out. RBC believes Zoom can become the "de facto global communication platform", estimating Covid-19 could add $160m of revenue this year and $257m next year. But Credit Suisse expects the recent surge will prove "ephemeral" and free users will be difficult to monetise. With the free tier allowing group chats for up to 100 participants for under 40 minutes, there is little incentive to pay a subscription. Facebook's new Messenger Rooms could spoil the party, allowing meetings of up to 50 people, including those without an account, with no time limit.

On the enterprise front, Microsoft Teams is the most significant competitive threat. With over 200m commercial users of Office 365, this provide a natural platform to promote Teams, which has surpassed 75m daily active users, up from 20m at the end of last year. Zoom is more of a one-trick pony, while Microsoft is a better overall bet with its arsenal of technology, including cloud computing infrastructure.

Zoom's shares were expensive pre-pandemic and an enterprise value of 31 times forecast 2021 revenue is far greater than software peers with multiples in the mid-teens. Scott Galloway, professor of marketing at New York University's Stern School of Business, believes Zoom is "priced to mania". Perhaps sensing a bubble, short sellers have renewed their charge.

Intuitively, there is a long-term investment case if the shift towards remote working sticks. Zoom has proved popular because it is easy to use, reliable and fun. But further skeletons could see the boom give way to a backlash. This is one bandwagon we're happy to let roll by.

Thriving in chaos

The market volatility caused by Covid-19 has seen a surge in trading activity - good news for online platforms IG (IGG), Plus500 (PLUS) and CMC Markets (CMCX), which had been weighed down by European Union (EU) regulation to reduce the risk of big losses for retail investors.

Making money through commissions and spreads on its leveraged products, IG's revenue in just the first 36 days of its current quarter is estimated to be £173m, more than the £140m posted in the entire preceding quarter. With the 'Corona crunch' plastered across the news, and casinos and sporting activity pared back, more people are taking a gamble on the stock market. IG added 22,500 over-the-counter clients during those 36 days, compared with 36,000 in the first three quarters of the year combined.

Plus500 saw sales in the first quarter of 2020 surge almost fivefold year on year to $317m (£254m), with the number of active customers nearly doubling. Full-year earnings are now guided to be "substantially ahead" of consensus expectations. The improved outlook has seen short interest fall from over 12 per cent of the issued share capital at the beginning of the year to less than 1 per cent.

But there's no such thing as a free lunch. IG's boost will be offset by higher operating costs, partially due to higher provisions for bad and doubtful debts. There's also a question of whether the 'good times' will last. The Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE) Volatility Index - a measure of future expectations of volatility - is now tracking downwards and retail investors are more likely to retreat amid fatigue and mounting losses. Meanwhile, platforms face the prospect of Australian regulators emulating their European counterparts.

While Berkshire Hathaway's (US:BRK.A) recent $50bn net loss may have taken some shine off of the 'Sage of Omaha', we're still inclined to favour Warren Buffett's philosophy: "Be fearful when others are greedy, and greedy only when others are fearful". The immediate opportunities of the pandemic have likely now passed. Unless you have a high appetite for risk and short time horizon, it is best to consider quality companies doing well in this crisis, but also underpinned by a long-term growth story. The hot stock du jour may be calling out to you, but don't be afraid to take the advice of a famous Disney queen and "let it go".
